title: 111_hr2274
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Priorities in Education Spending Act" and pertains to elementary and secondary education programs. The "Priorities in Education Spending Act" repeals various provisions of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 related to family literacy programs, school libraries, Close Up Fellowship program, comprehensive school reform, school leadership, and advanced certification. The "Priorities in Education Spending Act" repeals provisions related to various education programs such as family literacy, school libraries, comprehensive school reform, school leadership, technology enhancement, and immigrant education. The "Priorities in Education Spending Act" repeals provisions related to various education programs, including elementary and secondary school counseling, smaller learning communities, Reading is Fundamental book distribution, Star Schools Act, Ready to Teach program, Foreign Language Assistance Act of 2001, and the Carol M. White Physical Education Program. The "Priorities in Education Spending Act" repeals provisions related to various education programs, including elementary and secondary school counseling, smaller learning communities, Reading is Fundamental book distribution, Star Schools Act, Ready to Teach program, Foreign Language Assistance Act of 2001, and several subparts of part D of title V focusing on community technology centers, educational and cultural programs for Alaska Natives and Native Hawaiians, mental health grants for children, arts in education, and healthy, high-performance schools. The curr_chunk discusses different parts of title V and title VII related to educational assistance programs for certain local agencies, women's equity in education, Native Hawaiian education, and Alaska Native educational support. The Early Learning Opportunities Act (Title VIII of H.R. 5656) from the 106th Congress is repealed. Additionally, higher education programs are addressed in the following section. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is being amended to repeal several provisions, including sections related to Alaska Native and Native Hawaiian-serving Institutions, Byrd Honors Scholarships, TEACH Grants, Default Reduction Management program, loan repayment for civil legal assistance attorneys, the Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program, and part D of title VII. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is being amended to repeal several provisions, including sections related to various programs such as demonstration projects for students with disabilities, College Access Challenge Grant program, business workforce partnerships, Patsy Mink Fellowship program, Early Childhood Education Professional Development, and improving STEM education. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is being amended to include provisions related to improving STEM education for Alaska Native and Native Hawaiian students, pilot programs for college persistence, low tuition, cooperative education, creating bridges from jobs to careers, grants to rural-serving institutions, training for realtime writers, and Modeling and Simulation programs. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is being amended to include provisions related to improving STEM education for Alaska Native and Native Hawaiian students, pilot programs for college persistence, low tuition, cooperative education, creating bridges from jobs to careers, grants to rural-serving institutions, training for realtime writers, and various specific programs under different parts of title VIII. Additionally, certain provisions of the Higher Education Amendments of 1998 and other higher education laws are being repealed. The following sections are repealed:
(1) Section 121 of the Education of the Deaf Act of 1986 (20 U.S.C. 4341; Cultural Experiences Grants).
(2) Section 802 of the Higher Education Opportunity Act (20 U.S.C. 9631; National Center for Research in Advanced Information and Digital Technologies).
(3) Section 5(c) of the Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 (15 U.S.C. 3704(c); Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology Opportunity Program).
(4) Part E of title XV of the Higher Education Amendments of 1992 (20 U.S.C. 1070 note; B.J. Stupak Olympic Scholarships). SEC. 5. LITERACY PROGRAM FOR PRISONERS. The Secretary cannot use funds for prisoner literacy under the National Literacy Act of 1991.

SEC. 6. LOAN REPAYMENT FOR PROSECUTORS AND PUBLIC DEFENDERS. Repeals loan repayment for prosecutors and public defenders.

SEC. 7. CAREER AND TECHNICAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS. Repeals Title II of the Carl D. Perkins Career and Technical Education Act of 2006.

SEC. 8. SPECIAL OLYMPICS SPORT AND EMPOWERMENT ACT OF 2004 PROGRAM. SEC. 8. SPECIAL OLYMPICS SPORT AND EMPOWERMENT ACT OF 2004 PROGRAM is repealed. SEC. 9. HEAD START ACT PROGRAM is repealed. SEC. 10. WORKFORCE INVESTMENT ACT PROGRAM is repealed. SEC. 11. THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION ACT is repealed. SEC. 12. AMERICA COMPETES ACT is repealed. The America COMPETES Act is repealed, including provisions related to teachers, promising practices, summer term education programs, and Mathematics and Science Partnership Bonus Grants.
